structured_info.title_en: A control strategy for merging a single vehicle into a platoon at highway on-ramps
structured_info.abstract: This paper proposes a decentralized control strategy for merging a single cooperative automated vehicle (CAV) into a platoon at highway on-ramps. The strategy combines CACC feedback, gap-opening, and MPC controllers to handle large initial state differences, sensor noise, and disturbances from platoon leaders. It ensures smooth controller transitions, incorporates collision avoidance mechanisms, and achieves efficient, safe merging validated through simulations with communication delays and noise.
structured_info.methodology: Combination of CACC feedback control, gap-opening controllers, and model predictive control (MPC) for trajectory planning. Uses virtual transitional CACC controllers for smooth switching between control modes and collision avoidance algorithms for safety.
structured_info.conclusion: The proposed strategy outperforms traditional MPC methods in noise handling, safety, and passenger comfort. It successfully merges vehicles under large initial state differences and disturbances, forming steady-state platoons with minimal errors and jerk within acceptable bounds.
structured_info.venue: Transportation Research Part C: Emerging Technologies

analysis.Overview: Proposes a decentralized control strategy for merging a single automated vehicle into a platoon at highway on-ramps. Focuses on handling large initial state differences, noise, disturbances, and smooth controller transitions using CACC, gap-opening, and MPC approaches.
Background_and_Motivation: Addresses road safety and traffic congestion challenges in transportation systems. Cooperative adaptive cruise control (CACC) improves safety and throughput but merging vehicles into platoons at on-ramps remains complex.
Existing MPC-based strategies suffer from noise sensitivity and abrupt controller switching, leading to unsafe excitations. Fuzzy controllers struggle with large initial state differences.
Large velocity disparities between on-ramp vehicles (âˆ¼55 km/h) and main-lane platoons (âˆ¼100 km/h) necessitate robust solutions. Timely merging within spatial constraints of on-ramps is critical.
The problem links to broader challenges of CAV coordination in dynamic environments. Smooth controller transitions and noise robustness are urgent for real-world deployment.
Contributes to automotive control, intelligent transportation systems, and decentralized multi-agent control systems.
